properties.name: Carlos Bulosan (c. 1913-1956)
properties.description: English-language Filipino writer best remembered for his semi-autobiographical America is in the Heart. In the 1930s Bulosan lived in the historic Eastern Hotel, which hosts a permanent exhibit in his honor.

properties.name: Octavia Butler (1947-2006)
properties.description: Renowned speculative fiction writer and author of Parable of the Sower and Kindred, among other books. She lived in Seattle from 1999 until her death in 2006, and loved to eat at the Royal Palm restaurant in the University District.

properties.name: Horace R. Cayton Sr. (1859-1940)
properties.description: Prominent Black journalist who published the Seattle Republican newspaper from 1894-1913. His family home on Capitol Hill was designated a city landmark in 2021.

properties.name: Beverly Cleary (1916-2021)
properties.description: Beloved creator of Ramona Quimby who received her library science degree from University of Washington in 1939. The UW Information School now has an endowed chair for Children and Youth Services to honor her.

properties.name: Ivan Doig (1939-2015)
properties.description: Recipient of the prestigious Wallace Stegner Award, Doig is best known for his memoir This House of Sky: Landscapes of a Western Mind and his bestselling novel The Whistling Season. He received his Ph.D from the University of Washington and lived in Seattle until his death in 2015.

properties.name: Frank Herbert (1920-1986)
properties.description: Best known for his landmark science fiction novel Dune and its sequels, Herbert wrote for the Seattle Post-Intelligencer in the early 1970s. He was posthumously inducted into MoPOP’s Science Fiction Hall of Fame in 2006.

properties.name: Vi taqᵂšǝblu Hilbert (1918-2008)
properties.description: Upper Skagit elder who was a storyteller and dedicated conservationist of Lushootseed culture and language. She was the author of Haboo: Native American Stories from Puget Sound and she co-authored the second Lushootseed dictionary.

properties.name: Richard Hugo (1923-1982)
properties.description: Acclaimed poet born in White Center. Hugo studied under Theodore Roethke at the University of Washington and was a regular at the Triangle Pub and Blue Moon Tavern. Hugo House is named for him.

properties.name: Denise Levertov (1923-1997)
properties.description: Prolific poet and recipient of the Lannan Literary Award. She lived in Seattle from 1989 until her death in 1997. She is buried at Lake View Cemetery in Capitol Hill.

properties.name: Murray Morgan (1916-2000)
properties.description: Author of Skid Road: An Informal Portrait of Seattle. The term “skid road” originally referred to a logging road used to “skid” trees to the mill. Yesler Street was Seattle’s skid road and Henry Yesler’s mill stood at this intersection. The contemporary meaning of “skid road” as a poor urban area may have originated in Seattle in the 1850s.

properties.name: John Okada (1923-1971)
properties.description: Author of the seminal novel about Japanese incarceration, No-No Boy. He was born in the family quarters of the hotel above the Merchants Cafe and Saloon.

properties.name: Lawney Reyes (1931-2022)
properties.description: Best known as an artist and designer, Reyes is the author of several books, including his memoir White Grizzly Bear’s Legacy: Learning to be Indian and a biography of his brother, Bernie Whitebear: An Urban Indian's Quest for Justice.

properties.name: Theodore Roethke (1908-1963)
properties.description: Celebrated poet who won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award (twice). A street behind the Blue Moon Tavern was named for him because he held ‘symposia formal and informal' and ‘celebrated his receipt of both the Pulitzer and Bollingen prizes’ there.

properties.name: Raúl "Tapon" Salinas (1934-2008)
properties.description: Salinas was a Chicano poet, memoirist, social activist, and prison journalist who attended the University of Washington and later taught Chicano literature there. He was also involved in the development of El Centro de la Raza.

properties.name: Spencer Shaw (1916-2010)
properties.description: University of Washington professor emeritus of library science and nationally recognized storyteller and advocate for children’s reading. An endowed lecture series at the University of Washington is named in his honor.

properties.name: Ruben Sierra (1946-1998)
properties.description: Sierra was a playwright, actor, University of Washington Drama School faculty member, founding artistic director of the multicultural Seattle Group Theatre, and director of the University of Washington Ethnic Cultural Center and Theater.

properties.name: Chief Si'Ahl (c. 1786-1866)
properties.description: Important Suquamish and Duwamish chief, for whom Seattle is named. The name “Seattle” is an Anglicization of Si'ahl, the modern Duwamish spelling of siʔaɫ. A famous speech advocating ecological responsibility is attributed to him.

properties.name: Monica Sone (1919-2011)
properties.description: Japanese American writer best known for her memoir Nisei Daughter. She and Betty MacDonald both resided at Firland Sanatorium to recover from tuberculosis.

properties.name: Victorio Acosta Velasco (1902-1968)
properties.description: Filipino American journalist, best known as the founder, publisher and editor of The Filipino Forum (1928-1969), a bi-weekly newspaper billed as the “Independent Organ of Filipinos in the Pacific Northwest.”

properties.name: August Wilson (1945-2005)
properties.description: Multi-Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, Wilson is best known for his ten-play series The Pittsburgh Cycle, which includes Fences, The Piano Lesson, and Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom. He lived in Seattle from 1990 until his death in 2005.
